EU policies aim to ensure the free movement of people, goods, services, and capital within the internal market, enact legislation in justice and home affairs, and maintain common policies on trade, agriculture, fisheries, and regional development. Within the Schengen Area, passport controls have been abolished. A monetary union was established in 1999 and came into full force in 2002, and is composed of 19 EU member states which use the euro currency.  - Conceptual art, sometimes simply called conceptualism, is art in which the concept(s) or idea(s) involved in the work take precedence over traditional aesthetic and material concerns. Some works of conceptual art, sometimes called installations, may be constructed by anyone simply by following a set of written instructions. This method was fundamental to American artist Sol LeWitt's definition of Conceptual art, one of the first to appear in print:  - An artist is a person engaged in one or more of any of a broad spectrum of activities related to creating art, practicing the arts or demonstrating an art. The common usage in both everyday speech and academic discourse is a practitioner in the visual arts only. "Artiste" (the French for artist) is a variant used in English only in this context. It borders Norway to the west and Finland to the east, and is connected to Denmark in the southwest by a bridge-tunnel across the Öresund. At , Sweden is the third-largest country in the European Union by area, with a total population of 10.0 million. Sweden consequently has a low population density of , with the highest concentration in the southern half of the country. Approximately 85% of the population lives in urban areas.  - Copying is the duplication of information or an artifact based only on an instance of that information or artifact, and not using the process that originally generated it. With analog forms of information, copying is only possible to a limited degree of accuracy, which depends on the quality of the equipment used and the skill of the operator. There is some inevitable deterioration and accumulation of "noise" (random small changes, not sound) from original to copy; when successive generations of copy are made, this deterioration accumulates with each generation. With digital forms of information, copying is perfect. Estonia is south of the country across the Gulf of Finland. Finland is a Nordic country situated in the geographical region of Fennoscandia, which also includes Scandinavia. Finland's population is 5.5 million (2014), staying roughly on the same level over the past two decades. The majority of the population is concentrated in the southern region. In terms of area, it is the eighth largest country in Europe and the most sparsely populated country in the European Union.  - Cultural heritage is the legacy of physical science artifacts and intangible attributes of a group or society that are inherited from past generations, maintained in the present and bestowed for the benefit of future generations. Cultural heritage includes tangible culture (such as buildings, monuments, landscapes, books, works of art, and artifacts), intangible culture (such as folklore, traditions, language, and knowledge), and natural heritage (including culturally significant landscapes, and biodiversity).  - A biocurator is a professional scientist who curates, collects, annotates, and validates information that is disseminated by biological and model Organism Databases. The role of a biocurator encompasses quality control of primary biological research data intended for publication, extracting and organizing data from original scientific literature, and describing the data with standard annotation protocols and vocabularies that enable powerful queries and biological database inter-operability. Biocurators communicate with researchers to ensure the accuracy of curated information and to foster data exchanges with research laboratories.  - Northern Europe is the northern part or region of Europe. Although no definitive borders or definition exists for the term, geographically, Northern Europe may be considered to consist approximately of all of Europe above the 52nd parallel north; which includes (from west to east) most or all of: Iceland, the Republic of Ireland, the Isle of Man, the United Kingdom, the Faroe Islands, the Netherlands, northern Germany, Denmark, Norway, Sweden, northern Poland, Finland, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania and northwest Russia. However, narrower definitions may also be used based on other geographical factors, such as climate and ecology. Before this, all forms of electronic communication (early radio, telephone, and telegraph) were one-to-one, with the message intended for a single recipient. The term "broadcasting", borrowed from the agricultural method of sowing seeds in a field by casting them broadly about, was coined by either KDKA manager Frank Conrad or RCA historian George Clark around 1920 to distinguish this new activity of "one-to-many" communication; a single radio station transmitting to multiple listeners.  - An architect is someone who plans, designs, and reviews the construction of buildings. Traditionally, a curator or keeper of a cultural heritage institution (e.g., gallery, museum, library, or archive) is a content specialist charged with an institution's collections and involved with the interpretation of heritage material. A traditional curator's concern necessarily involves tangible objects of some sortartwork, collectibles, historic items, or scientific collections. More recently, new kinds of curators have started to emerge: curators of digital data objects and biocurators.  - Europe is a continent that comprises the westernmost part of Eurasia. Europe is bordered by the Arctic Ocean to the north, the Atlantic Ocean to the west, and the Mediterranean Sea to the south. To the east and southeast, Europe is generally considered as separated from Asia by the watershed divides of the Ural and Caucasus Mountains, the Ural River, the Caspian and Black Seas, and the waterways of the Turkish Straits. input:
Summarize:

The 11-year-old from Coatbridge in North Lanarkshire was last seen on a bus in 1957.
The Crown said earlier this year the bus driver, Alexander Gartshore, would have been tried for her murder if he was still alive.
Its now considering the next steps in the investigation.
Moira's body has never been found. Specialists in soil science have now identified a number of sites where her remains might be buried.
Prof Lorna Dawson, geoforensics expert from the James Hutton Institute in Aberdeen, was enlisted earlier this year to help in the search for the schoolgirl's remains.
BBC Scotland reported last month that she was understood to have prepared a forensic report based on her initial investigations.
The Crown Office has now met her and said it would decide in due course which areas would be searched.
A spokesman said: "The Lord Advocate held a positive meeting with forensic expert Prof Lorna Dawson of the James Hutton Institute and DS Pat Campbell of Police Scotland and the Crown will now consider the next steps in the investigation into the murder of Moira Anderson.
"Specialist work in the field of soil science and geographical information has allowed investigators to narrow down the number of possible locations for the whereabouts of Moira's remains and a decision on the search areas will be made in due course."
Moira Anderson was last seen on 23 February 1957.
After leaving her grandmother's house, she boarded a Baxter's bus that was driven by Gartshore.
Later that year, he was jailed for raping a 17-year-old babysitter.
In 1999, convicted child abuser James Gallogley named his former friend Gartshore as Moira's murderer.
output: In 1957, 11-year-old Moira Anderson from Coatbridge in North Lanarkshire disappeared, and her body was never found. The Crown claimed that if bus driver Alexander Gartshore were alive today, he would have been tried for her murder. A geoforensics expert, Professor Lorna Dawson from the James Hutton Institute, was enlisted to help search for Moira's remains, with soil science specialists identifying several potential burial sites. The Crown Office will decide which areas to search in due course as they consider next steps in the investigation. Gartshore was jailed later in 1957 for raping a 17-year-old and was named as Moira's murderer by convicted child abuser James Gallogley in 1999.

Now they're considering the next steps in the investigation.

Moira's body hasn't been found yet. They've brought in experts in soil science to identify possible sites where her remains might be buried. Professor Lorna Dawson from the James Hutton Institute in Aberdeen was called in earlier this year to help search for Moira. The BBC reported that she prepared a forensic report based on her initial work.

The Crown Office met with her and will decide soon which areas to search. A spokesperson mentioned a positive meeting with Prof Dawson and DS Pat Campbell from Police Scotland. They also noted that soil science and geographical info helped narrow down possible locations, and a decision on the search areas will be made later.

Moira was last seen on February 23, 1957. She left her grandmother's house and took a bus driven by Gartshore. Later that year, he was jailed for raping a 17-year-old babysitter. In 1999, another convicted child abuser, James Gallogley, named Gartshore as Moira's murderer.

- Moira was 11, last seen in 1957 on a bus driven by Gartshore.

system_prompt: You are an AI assistant. User will you give you a task. Your goal is to complete the task as faithfully as you can. While performing the task think step-by-step and justify your steps.
input:
Article: If you are moving to France, you’ll want to spend some time learning at least a little bit of the French language. You’ll need to be able to talk to people when you rent a property, find a job, order food in a restaurant, and in almost every other aspect of your life in France. Learning the language is crucial.  Try hiring a French tutor, taking a class at a university, using an online program like Rosetta Stone, or a fun learning app like Duolingo. If you move to a major metropolitan area like Paris, it is likely that you will encounter people who speak English quite regularly. However, if you are moving to a more rural area, you will need to speak French to get by in your day-to-day life. The location you move to in France may depend on your job, or it may be a little more open to selection for you. If you can choose, think about where you would like to go to in France.  If you want to live in a city with more job opportunities and that may be easier for a foreigner to integrate, consider Paris, Toulouse, or Lyon. If you want a more quaint French countryside experience, consider moving to a more rural location with a smaller population. You may wish to stay in furnished housing, or if you are shipping some items you may prefer to get an unfurnished flat. There are many options for places to live in France, so consider which one will be the best for you.  The Internet can be a good source of accommodations, especially sites that cater to those emigrating to France. Try searching on sites like SeLoger, PAP, or Lodgis. If you want to find a traditional apartment in France, be aware that there are some things to consider. For example, if you don’t earn an income that is three times the rent, you will be asked to provide a guarantor (like a co-signer on a loan) who will be legally responsible to pay for you if you aren’t able to pay your rent. This person must be someone who earns income in France – so it can’t be your parents back in your home country – which can cause problems for people initially moving to a new country. If you are planning on living in France for a shorter period of time (a matter of months, rather than years), you may want to consider renting a place on a website like AirBnb. This option might be a bit more expensive than obtaining a traditional apartment, but it will save you the hassle of searching for an apartment in person when you arrive in France, securing a guarantor, signing up for renter’s insurance, activating utilities in your home, furnishing your apartment, etc. Search for flights on the Internet and try to find the best deal. Spend some time looking and consider all of your options. You could also go through a travel agent if you are not comfortable booking the flight yourself.  When booking your flight, consider things like layovers and travel time. If you are checking a bunch of bags, the more layovers you have the more likely it is that all of your bags won’t arrive with you. If you are bringing a pet with you on the aeroplane, you may want to pay a little extra for a direct flight to limit your travel time. Keep in mind that return flights are almost always less expensive than one-way flights. So, even if you don’t plan to return to your country of origin, you might want to consider purchasing a return ticket anyway. Ship valuables that you cannot take with you on the plane ahead to France. There are many shipping services you can utilize, but be aware of French governmental restrictions on shipping personal items.  These restrictions may vary, but as of 2010 include: Firearms, ammunition, meat, dairy products, plants, narcotics, psychotropic substances, pets, medicine, precious metals, cash, counterfeit items, and wild animals. If you want to bring your family pets with you to France, you will have to make sure your pet’s vaccinations (especially rabies) are up to date, have your vet complete a health clearance travel form (and possibly get this form stamped by your country’s import/export authority), and ensure that your pet has been microchipped. France may require additional measures to be taken for pets being imported from certain countries.  Before shipping any items to France, check with the French Consulate to be sure that you have the updated shipping restrictions.

What is a summary?
output: The article provides tips for those who are planning to move to France. It emphasizes the importance of learning French and suggests various ways to do so. It also discusses factors to consider when choosing a location to live in France and provides options for finding accommodations. The article also gives advice on booking flights and shipping personal items, including pets, to France.
distill_llama_output:
Okay, so the user has provided a detailed article about moving to France, covering various aspects like learning French, choosing a place to live, finding accommodation, booking flights, shipping items, and pet requirements. They're asking for a summary. 

First, I need to identify the main sections of the article. The article starts with the importance of learning French, which is crucial for daily life. Then it talks about choosing between urban and rural areas, which is influenced by job opportunities and personal preferences. 

Next, the section on finding accommodation mentions traditional apartments and the need for a guarantor, which is a key point because it affects how someone can secure housing. There's also an option for short-term rentals like AirBnB, which is useful for those not planning to stay long-term.

When it comes to flights, the article advises considering layovers, baggage, pets, and return tickets. These are practical tips that can save money and hassle. 

Shipping valuables is another important part, with specific restrictions listed. This is crucial for someone moving to ensure they don't bring prohibited items. Lastly, bringing pets requires certain health documents, which is a detail that shouldn't be overlooked.

I should structure the summary to cover each of these areas succinctly. Starting with language, then location choice, accommodation options, flight booking tips, shipping considerations, and pet requirements. Each of these points should be a bullet point for clarity. 

I also need to make sure the summary is concise but covers all the essential aspects mentioned in the article. The user likely wants a quick overview, so avoiding too much detail is key. 

I should start each point with a clear heading, use bullet points for readability, and ensure each section is brief but informative. This way, the user can easily grasp the main points without getting overwhelmed by too much information.

Finally, I'll make sure the summary flows logically from one topic to the next, providing a comprehensive yet streamlined overview of what someone needs to consider when moving to France.
</think>

**Summary of Moving to France:**

1. **Language Learning**: Mastering French is essential for daily life in France, including interactions for housing, employment, and social activities.

2. **Location Choice**: 
   - Urban areas like Paris, Toulouse, or Lyon offer job opportunities and are more accessible for foreigners.
   - Rural areas provide a quaint, traditional French experience.

3. **Accommodation Options**:
   - **Traditional Apartments**: Requires a guarantor with income in France, which can be challenging for newcomers.
   - **Short-Term Rentals (AirBnB)**: Suitable for temporary stays, though costlier than traditional apartments.

4. **Flight Booking**:
   - Consider layovers, baggage policies, and direct flights for pets.
   - Return flights are often cheaper, even if a return isn’t planned.

5. **Shipping Considerations**:
   - Prohibited items include firearms, meat, dairy, plants, narcotics, pets (without proper documentation), and more.
   - Check with the French Consulate for updated restrictions.

6. **Pet Requirements**:
   - Ensure pets have up-to-date vaccinations, a health clearance form, and microchipping.
   - Additional measures may apply for pets from certain countries.

Detailed Instructions: In this task, you are given a sentence from the research paper and the category to which it belongs. Your task is to classify whether the given category is correct or not by providing "True" and "False", respectively. Here are the definitions for the categories: Background (Why is this problem important? What relevant works have been created before? What is still missing in the previous works? What are the high-level research questions? How might this help other research or researchers?), Purpose (What specific things do the researchers want to do? What specific knowledge do the researchers want to gain? What specific hypothesis do the researchers want to test?), Method (How did the researchers do the work or find what they sought? What are the procedures and steps of the research?), or Finding (What did the researchers find out? Did the proposed methods work? Did the thing behave as the researchers expected?). ",
Q: Sentence: Over 20,000 people have received the vaccine in clinical trials ; the vaccine has proven to be safe and well tolerated. 
 Section: method
A:
output:
True. 

Explanation: The sentence describes the clinical trials and the safety of the vaccine, which falls under the category of Method as it explains how the researchers conducted their work and what procedures they followed. Therefore, the given category is correct.
distill_llama_output:
Okay, so I'm trying to figure out whether the given sentence belongs to the "Method" category or not. The sentence is: "Over 20,000 people have received the vaccine in clinical trials; the vaccine has proven to be safe and well tolerated." The task is to classify this into one of the categories: Background, Purpose, Method, or Finding. 

First, I need to understand each category's definition to accurately categorize the sentence. Let me go through each one.

Background: This category is about why the problem is important, what previous works exist, what's missing in those works, high-level research questions, and how it helps others. So, if the sentence is talking about the importance of the vaccine or what prior studies have done, it would be Background.

Purpose: This is about what the researchers want to do specifically, the knowledge they aim to gain, and any hypotheses they're testing. If the sentence outlines the main goals or objectives of the study, it falls under Purpose.

Method: This involves how the researchers conducted their work, the procedures and steps they took. If the sentence describes the processes or methods used, like the clinical trials mentioned, it's Method.

Finding: This is about what the researchers found, whether the methods worked, and how the thing behaved compared to expectations. If the sentence talks about results or outcomes, it's Finding.

Looking at the sentence again: It mentions that over 20,000 people received the vaccine in clinical trials and that the vaccine was safe and well-tolerated. This seems to be describing the process of how the vaccine was tested, which is a method of research. They're talking about the procedure (clinical trials) and the outcome (safety and tolerance) from that method. 

Wait, but I'm a bit confused. Is the part about the vaccine being safe and well-tolerated a finding or part of the method? The method would include the process, like the trials, while the finding is the result of those trials, which is that the vaccine is safe. So, maybe the first part is method, and the second part is finding.

But the sentence combines both. It says they did the trials and that the vaccine was safe. So, perhaps the entire sentence is describing the method used (the clinical trials) and the outcome (the safety and tolerance), which are both part of the Method category because they're detailing how the research was conducted and the results from that method.

Alternatively, maybe the second part is a Finding because it's stating what they found out about the vaccine. So, perhaps the sentence includes both, but the primary focus is on the method. 

I think the key here is whether the sentence is explaining the procedure or the result. Since it starts with how many people received the vaccine in trials and then states the outcome, it's a bit of both. But since the main focus is on the process (how they tested it) and the outcome from that process, it might lean more towards Method because it's explaining the methods used in the research.

I'm a bit torn, but I think the sentence is describing the method because it's detailing the steps taken (clinical trials with a large number of participants) and the outcome of those steps (vaccine is safe). So, it's explaining the method used and the resulting findings from that method. Therefore, it's part of the Method category.
</think>

The sentence describes the process of conducting clinical trials and the outcomes observed, which fall under the Method category as it details the research procedures and results from those methods.

Answer: True

Answer the following question: I want to test the ability of students to read a passage and answer questions about it. Could you please come up with a good question for the passage "The existence of discrete inheritable units was first suggested by Gregor Mendel (1822–1884). From 1857 to 1864, he studied inheritance patterns in 8000 common edible pea plants, tracking distinct traits from parent to offspring. He described these mathematically as 2n combinations where n is the number of differing characteristics in the original peas. Although he did not use the term gene, he explained his results in terms of discrete inherited units that give rise to observable physical characteristics. This description prefigured the distinction between genotype (the genetic material of an organism) and phenotype (the visible traits of that organism). Mendel was also the first to demonstrate independent assortment, the distinction between dominant and recessive traits, the distinction between a heterozygote and homozygote, and the phenomenon of discontinuous inheritance."?

output:
Question: 

1. Who first suggested the existence of discrete inheritable units and during what period did he study this? 

2. What method did he use to describe these inheritable units mathematically? 

3. How did Gregor Mendel explain his results in terms of inherited units? 

4. Explain the concepts of genotype, phenotype, dominant and recessive traits, heterozygote, homozygote, and discontinuous inheritance as introduced by Mendel. 

5. What was Mendel's achievement with regard to the independent assortment?

Justification:

1. This question tests basic comprehension, asking the reader to identify key details from the passage.
   
2. This question tests the reader's understanding of the specific processes and methodologies associated with Mendel's research.

3. This question requires the reader not only to remember the details but also understand the underlying scientific concept Mendel was trying to explain.

4. This question is for the reader's comprehension of key terminologies and concepts in genetics discussed in the passage.

5. The last question examines the reader's understanding of the broader implications and achievements of Mendel's work. It asks the reader to analyze the material and draw a conclusion about Mendel's impact on the field of genetics.

Putting it together, a question like: "What did Gregor Mendel's work prefigure, as described in the passage?" Detailed Instructions: In this task you are given a list of numbers and you need to find the average of each two consecutive values. The average of two numbers a and b is calculated as: (a + b) /2. The output should be a list of the averages of each two consecutive values. A list is presented with two brackets and comma-separated values, like: [1,2,3].
Q: [1, 17, 63, 14, -77, 7, 58, -16, -96, 5, 81, 59]
A:
output:
To find the average of each two consecutive values in the given list [1, 17, 63, 14, -77, 7, 58, -16, -96, 5, 81, 59], we need to iterate through the list and calculate the average of each pair of consecutive values. Here are the steps to do that:

1. Create an empty list to store the averages.
2. Iterate through the list using a for loop, starting from the second element (index 1) and ending at the second last element (index len(list)-1).
3. For each pair of consecutive values, calculate the average using the formula (a + b) / 2, where a and b are the two consecutive values.
4. Append the average to the empty list created in step 1.
5. After the loop is finished, return the list of averages.

Here's the Python code to implement the above steps:

```
def find_averages(lst):
    averages = []
    for i in range(1, len(lst)):
        avg = (lst[i-1] + lst[i]) / 2
        averages.append(avg)
    return averages
```

To use this function with the given list [1, 17, 63, 14, -77, 7, 58, -16, -96, 5, 81, 59], simply call the function and pass the list as an argument:

```
>>> lst = [1, 17, 63, 14, -77, 7, 58, -16, -96, 5, 81, 59]
>>> find_averages(lst)
[9.0, 40.0, 38.5, -31.5, -35.0, 32.5, 21.0, -56.0, -45.5, 43.0, 70.0]
```

The output is a list of the averages of each two consecutive values in the original list.

After calculating all the averages, I'll compile them into a list in the required format.
</think>

**Solution:**

We are given the list of numbers:
\[ [1, 17, 63, 14, -77, 7, 58, -16, -96, 5, 81, 59] \]

To find the average of each two consecutive values, we follow these steps:

1. **Pair the numbers:**
   - (1, 17)
   - (63, 14)
   - (-77, 7)
   - (58, -16)
   - (-96, 5)
   - (81, 59)

2. **Calculate the average for each pair:**
   - \(\frac{1 + 17}{2} = \frac{18}{2} = 9\)
   - \(\frac{63 + 14}{2} = \frac{77}{2} = 38.5\)
   - \(\frac{-77 + 7}{2} = \frac{-70}{2} = -35\)
   - \(\frac{58 + (-16)}{2} = \frac{42}{2} = 21\)
   - \(\frac{-96 + 5}{2} = \frac{-91}{2} = -45.5\)
   - \(\frac{81 + 59}{2} = \frac{140}{2} = 70\)

3. **Compile the results into a list:**
   \[ [9, 38.5, -35, 21, -45.5, 70] \]

**Final Answer:**
\[
\boxed{[9, 38.5, -35, 21, -45.5, 70]}
\]

**Movie Plot: "The Tana Leaf Secret"**

**Introduction:**
Professor Norman, a renowned scientist with a reputation for his ethical research, is working on a groundbreaking discovery in the ancient ruins of an undisclosed location. His findings could revolutionize the field of medicine and energy, but the discovery is guarded by a powerful, ancient force.

**Act 1: The Discovery and the Antagonist**
While exploring the ruins, Norman stumbles upon a hidden chamber containing a mysterious fluid extracted from tana leaves. The fluid, known as the "Elixir of Knowledge," is said to grant its drinker the ability to unlock hidden truths and harness powerful energies. However, the chamber is guarded by Kharis, a shadowy figure with a dangerous agenda. Kharis believes the Elixir is the key to an ancient power that could change the world, and he is determined to ensure that Norman either finds it or is eliminated.

**Conflict and Tension:**
Norman, who values morality and integrity, is hesitant to use the Elixir. Kharis, however, is relentless. He forces Norman to drink the fluid under threat of destroying everything Norman holds dear—his family, his research, and his reputation. The confrontation between the two is intense, with Kharis using psychological manipulation to break Norman's resolve.

**The Transformation:**
After the forced drinking, Norman undergoes a dramatic transformation. The Elixir reveals hidden strengths and knowledge, but it also introduces a moral dilemma. Norman gains the power to manipulate reality, but he struggles with the ethical implications of his new abilities. He begins to question whether he can control this power or if it will consume him.

**Act 2: The Rise of a Hero or a Villain**
As Norman grapples with his new powers, Kharis remains a constant threat. The two engage in a series of battles, both physical and ideological. Norman must decide whether to use his powers to defeat Kharis and protect the Elixir or to reject his transformation and find another way to stop Kharis. His choices will have far-reaching consequences.

**Climax and Aftermath:**
In the final showdown, Norman confronts Kharis in a high-stakes battle. The climax reaches its peak as Norman uses his newfound abilities to outsmart and defeat Kharis, but the victory comes at a personal cost. The Elixir has changed Norman, and he must now confront the consequences of his actions. Will he embrace his new power or seek a way to return to who he was?

**Ending:**
The movie concludes with Norman reflecting on his journey. He has saved the world from Kharis's threat but at the cost of his old self. The Elixir's effects are permanent, and Norman must now navigate a world that no longer understands him. The final scene hints at the possibility of a sequel or a new beginning, leaving the audience wondering about the future of this transformed hero.

**Themes:**
The film explores themes of power, morality, and the cost of knowledge. It delves into the consequences of one's actions and the thin line between good and evil. The relationship between Norman and Kharis adds emotional depth, highlighting the complexities of their motivations and the battles within their own psyches.

**Visual Style:**
The movie's setting is a mix of ancient ruins and modern technology, creating a mysterious and visually striking atmosphere. The fluid's appearance is otherworldly, with glowing hues and an ethereal quality that enhances the sense of danger and wonder.

**Supporting Characters:**
The plot is supported by Norman's colleagues, who are concerned about his disappearance, and a group of allies who join him in his fight against Kharis. These characters provide perspective and help drive the plot forward, adding layers to the narrative.

**Title:**
"The Tana Leaf Secret"

Please answer the following question: -  Water is absorbed through roots - Chloroplast cells in leaves contain chlorophyll - Chlorophyll absorbs energy from sunlight - Energy splits water molecules into hydrogen and oxygen - Oxygen gets released into atmosphere - Hydrogen and carbon dioxide used to create glucose - Glucose is food for plants.  What might be the first step of the process?
A:
output:
The first step of the process described is the absorption of water through the roots of the plant. Water is an essential component for plant growth and survival. The roots of plants have specialized structures called root hairs, which increase the surface area available for water absorption. These root hairs are in close contact with the soil, allowing them to absorb water and dissolved nutrients from the surrounding environment.

Water absorption through the roots is facilitated by a process called osmosis. Osmosis is the movement of water molecules from an area of higher water concentration (in the soil) to an area of lower water concentration (inside the plant's root cells). This movement occurs across a semipermeable membrane, which allows water molecules to pass through but restricts the movement of other dissolved substances.

The process of water absorption through the roots is driven by the plant's need for water to support various physiological functions. Water is essential for maintaining turgor pressure in plant cells, which helps to keep the plant upright and structurally stable. It is also involved in the transport of nutrients and minerals from the roots to other parts of the plant, such as the leaves and stems.

In addition to water absorption, the roots also play a role in anchoring the plant in the soil and providing support. They also serve as a storage organ for carbohydrates and other nutrients that the plant may need during periods of limited water availability.

Overall, the absorption of water through the roots is a crucial first step in the process of plant growth and survival. Without an adequate supply of water, plants would not be able to carry out essential functions such as photosynthesis, nutrient uptake, and maintaining their structural integrity.

So, putting this all together, the sequence starts with sunlight being absorbed by chlorophyll. Without sunlight, none of the other steps would happen because that's the initial energy source. So, the first step must be the absorption of sunlight by chlorophyll.

The first step of photosynthesis is the absorption of sunlight by chlorophyll in the chloroplasts of plant leaves. This is the initial process that provides the energy necessary for the subsequent steps, including the splitting of water molecules and the creation of glucose and oxygen. 

**Answer: A: Chlorophyll absorbs energy from sunlight.**

input: Write down the solution for this math problem: Solve 11050 = 230*m - 450 for m.
output:
To solve for m in the equation 11050 = 230*m - 450, we need to isolate the variable m on one side of the equation. 

First, we can add 450 to both sides of the equation to get:

11050 + 450 = 230*m - 450 + 450

This simplifies to:

11500 = 230*m

Next, we can divide both sides of the equation by 230 to get:

11500/230 = m

Simplifying this expression gives us:

50 = m

Therefore, the solution to the equation 11050 = 230*m - 450 is m = 50.

Next, I'll divide both sides of the equation by 230 to solve for m. This will isolate m on one side.

Finally, performing the division gives m as 50.

To solve the equation \( 11050 = 230 \times m - 450 \) for \( m \), follow these steps:

1. **Start with the original equation:**
   \[
   11050 = 230m - 450
   \]

2. **Add 450 to both sides to isolate the term with \( m \):**
   \[
   11050 + 450 = 230m
   \]
   \[
   11500 = 230m
   \]

3. **Divide both sides by 230 to solve for \( m \):**
   \[
   m = \frac{11500}{230}
   \]
   \[
   m = 50
   \]

**Final Answer:**
\[
\boxed{50}
\]

input: Information:  - William John Swainson FLS, FRS (8 October 1789  6 December 1855), was an English ornithologist, malacologist, conchologist, entomologist and artist.  - Nicholas Aylward Vigors (1785  26 October 1840) was an Irish zoologist and politician. He popularized the classification of birds on the basis of the quinarian system.  - William Sharp Macleay or McLeay (21 July 1792  26 January 1865) was a British civil servant and entomologist.  - Johann Jakob Kaup ( April 10 , 1803 - July 4 , 1873 ) was a German naturalist . A proponent of natural philosophy , he believed in an innate mathematical order in nature and he attempted biological classifications based on the Quinarian system .  - Philosophy (from Greek , "philosophia", literally "love of wisdom") is the study of general and fundamental problems concerning matters such as existence, knowledge, values, reason, mind, and language. The term was probably coined by Pythagoras (c. 570  c. 495 BC). Philosophical methods include questioning, critical discussion, rational argument and systematic presentation. Classic philosophical questions include: Is it possible to know anything and to prove it? What is most real? However, philosophers might also pose more practical and concrete questions such as: Is there a best way to live? Is it better to be just or unjust (if one can get away with it)? Do humans have free will?  - Johann Jakob Kaup (10 April 1803  4 July 1873) was a German naturalist. A proponent of natural philosophy, he believed in an innate mathematical order in nature and he attempted biological classifications based on the Quinarian system. Biography. He was born at Darmstadt. After studying at Göttingen and Heidelberg he spent two years at Leiden, where his attention was specially devoted to the amphibians and fishes. He then returned to Darmstadt as an assistant in the grand ducal museum, of which in 1840 he became inspector. In 1829 he published "Skizze zur Entwickelungsgeschichte der europäischen Thierwelt", in which he regarded the animal world as developed from lower to higher forms, from the amphibians through the birds to the beasts of prey; but subsequently he repudiated this work as a youthful indiscretion, and on the publication of Darwin's "Origin of Species" he declared himself against its doctrines. The extensive fossil deposits in the neighbourhood of Darmstadt gave him ample opportunities for palaeontological inquiries, and he gained considerable reputation by his "Beiträge zur näheren Kenntniss der urweltlichen Säugethiere" (18551862). He also wrote "Classification der Säugethiere und Vögel" (1844), and, with Heinrich Georg Bronn, "Die Gavial-artigen Reste aus dem Lias" (18421844).  - The Quinarian system was a method of zoological classification which had a brief period of popularity in the mid 19th century, especially among British naturalists. It was largely developed by the entomologist William Sharp MacLeay in 1819. The system was further promoted in the works of Nicholas Aylward Vigors, William John Swainson and Johann Jakob Kaup. Swainson's work on ornithology gave wide publicity to the idea. The system had opponents even before the publication of Charles Darwin's "On the Origin of Species" (1859 ) which paved the way for evolutionary trees.  - Natural philosophy or philosophy of nature (from Latin "philosophia naturalis") was the philosophical study of nature and the physical universe that was dominant before the development of modern science. input:
You will be given a definition of a task first, then some input of the task.
In this task you are given a tweet that contains some form of irony. You must classify the type of irony the tweet has. Label the tweets ("polarity","situational","other") based on the irony they have. Situational irony happens when a situation fails to meet some expectations, Label these instances as "situational". polarity irony happens when irony is achieved by inverting the intended sentence, Label these instances as "polarity". There are other kinds of ironies that are neither polarity nor situational, Label these instances as "other". Note that URLs in the text have been replaced with [Link].

Half the world is starving, the other half is struggling to lose weight! | #SickWorld
Output:
output:
To classify the type of irony present in the given tweet, let's analyze its content step-by-step:

1. Read and understand the tweet: "Half the world is starving, the other half is struggling to lose weight! | #SickWorld"
2. Identify the irony: The tweet highlights the contrasting situations of people around the world. On one hand, there are people who don't have enough food to eat, while on the other, some are trying to shed extra pounds. This irony is caused by contrasting situations failing to meet expectations, as one would not expect such stark differences in basic needs.
3. Classify the irony: Based on the definition provided, the irony in this tweet falls into the "situational" category, as it is based on a situation failing to meet expectations.

Output: situational
distill_llama_output:
Alright, I need to analyze this tweet to determine the type of irony it's using. The tweet says, "Half the world is starving, the other half is struggling to lose weight!" with the hashtag #SickWorld. 

First, I'll break down the sentence. It's a comparison between two groups: one that's starving and another that's trying to lose weight. This setup creates a contrast between extreme hunger and a desire to be thin, which is inherently contradictory. 

I remember that there are two main types of irony to classify here: polarity and situational. Polarity irony inverts the intended meaning, often using wordplay or double entendres. Situational irony occurs when the situation fails to meet expectations, leading to unintended humor or insight.

Looking at the tweet, it's using a surprising comparison to highlight a contradiction. The starving half and the weight loss struggle are opposite extremes. This creates a vivid image that's absurd and unlikely, which fits the definition of situational irony because it's based on an unexpected twist in a real-world scenario. It's not just wordplay but a clever use of context to create irony.

I don't think it's polarity irony because it's not inverting the meaning of words or phrases in a way that creates a double entendre. Instead, it's using the contrast between two situations to make a point, which aligns more with situational irony.

So, after considering both types, I'm confident that the tweet's irony is situational.
</think>

The tweet uses situational irony by highlighting a contradictory scenario where one group is starving while another is struggling to lose weight, creating an unexpected and absurd contrast.

**Answer:** (polarity)

input:
Answer the following question: Information:  - Mexico (, modern Nahuatl ), officially the United Mexican States, is a federal republic in the southern half of North America. It is bordered to the north by the United States; to the south and west by the Pacific Ocean; to the southeast by Guatemala, Belize, and the Caribbean Sea; and to the east by the Gulf of Mexico. Covering almost two million square kilometers (over 760,000 sq mi), Mexico is the sixth largest country in the Americas by total area and the 13th largest independent nation in the world. With an estimated population of over 120 million, it is the eleventh most populous country and the most populous Spanish-speaking country in the world while being the second most populous country in Latin America. Mexico is a federation comprising 31 states and a federal district that is also its capital and most populous city. Other metropolises include Guadalajara, Monterrey, Puebla, Toluca, Tijuana and León.  - Harris County is a county located in the U.S. state of Texas. As of the 2010 census, the population was 4,092,459, making it the most populous county in Texas and the third-most populous county in the United States. Its county seat is Houston, the largest city in Texas and fourth-largest city in the United States. The county was founded in 1836 and organized in 1837. It is named for John Richardson Harris, an early settler of the area.  - Buffalo Bayou is a shady, slow-moving river and a main waterway, known as the "Mother Bayou," flowing through Houston in Harris County, Texas. Formed some 18,000 years ago, it has its source in the rapidly developing prairie of Katy, Fort Bend County, Texas, and flows approximately east through the Houston Ship Channel and into Galveston Bay and the Gulf of Mexico. In addition to drainage water impounded and released by Addicks and Barker Dams, the bayou is fed by natural springs, surface runoff from streets, parking lots, and highways, and several significant tributary bayous, such as White Oak Bayou, Greens Bayou, and Brays Bayou.  - Fort Bend County is a county in the U.S. state of Texas. As of the 2010 census, its population was 585,375, making it the tenth-most populous county in Texas. Fort Bend County is the wealthiest county in Texas with a median household income of $95,389 and a median family income of $105,944, having surpassed Collin and Rockwall counties (Dallas suburbs) since the 2000 census. The county seat is Richmond, while its largest city is Sugar Land. The county was founded in 1837 and organized the next year. It is named for a blockhouse at a bend of the Brazos River; the fort was the start of the community in early days.  - The Addicks Reservoir and Addicks Dam in conjunction with the Barker Reservoir prevent downstream flooding of Buffalo Bayou in the City of Houston . Both reservoirs were authorized under the Rivers and Harbors Act of June 20 , 1938 , which were modified by the Flood Control Acts of August 11 , 1938 ; September 3 , 1954 ; and October 27 , 1965 .  - White Oak Bayou is one of the several waterways that give Houston, Texas, United States its popular nickname "The Bayou City." The Bayou originates northwest of FM 1960, near Highway 6 and U.S. Highway 290/Northwest Freeway, and meanders generally toward the southeast until it joins Buffalo Bayou in downtown Houston.  - The Gulf of Mexico is an ocean basin largely surrounded by the North American continent. It is bounded on the northeast, north and northwest by the Gulf Coast of the United States, on the southwest and south by Mexico, and on the southeast by Cuba. The U.S. states of Alabama, Florida, Louisiana, Mississippi and Texas border the Gulf on the north, which are often referred to as the "Third Coast" in comparison with the U.S. Atlantic and Pacific coasts, or sometimes the "south coast", in juxtaposition to the Great Lakes region being the "north coast." One of the gulf's seven main areas is the Gulf of Mexico basin.  - Houston is the most populous city in Texas and the fourth-most populous city in the United States after Chicago, located in Southeast Texas near the Gulf of Mexico. With a census-estimated 2014 population of 2.239 million within an area of , it also is the largest city in the Southern United States, as well as the seat of Harris County. Article: A 12-year old boy who donated bone marrow   to his dying sister and has raised more thanPS10,000 for charity has been named the UK's Family Hero of the Year. Adam Kerr, 12, from Armagh, Northern Ireland, also helps his mother care for his younger brother Brian, 9, who suffers from the genetic disease Fanconi's anaemia  . But it is not the first hardship that has affected young Adam. When he was just six, he donated his own bone marrow to his younger sister Helen who suffered from a rare blood disorder. Sadly she developed complications and died a few months after the operation in 2005. Adam found it very difficult to be happy after Helen's death. So he decided to start raising money in memory of Helen to help local poor children and families with bereavement  . Overall he has raised PS10,000 and he has no intentions of giving up. He organised a Fun Day to provide the money for a brother and sister from Northern Ireland to visit their sick brother having a bone marrow transplant in a London hospital. He received his award and a cheque forPS2,000 at an "Oscar's style" ceremony in London. Ms Phillips said: "Adam is an incredible young man. In his relatively short life he has faced real sadness and bad luck and yet he works tirelessly to make life better for others." The Awards were sponsored by the charity 4Children and Take a Break Magazine. Anne Longfield OBE, Chief Executive of 4Children said:"It's an honour to recognise Adam's devotion and self-sacrifice, and his bravery shows there is always reason for hope and optimism. There is so much unrecognized goodwill out there of people who do so much for others, and the inspiring winners of the Family Heroes Awards remind us how important it is for us all to do our best to make a difference in the lives of others." Question: What's the best title for the passage? - How to help others in trouble - A little boy makes a big difference to others - How to be a winner of the Family Heroes Awards - An independent young man
output: The best title for the passage is "A little boy makes a big difference to others".

Goaltenders tend to stay at or beyond the top of the crease to cut down on the angle of shots. In today's age of goaltending there are two common styles, butterfly and hybrid (hybrid is a mix of the traditional stand-up style and butterfly technique). Because of the power of shots, the goaltender wears special equipment designed to protect the body from direct impact. The goalie is one of the most valuable players on the ice, as their performance can greatly change the outcome or score of the game. Please write a short summary for the following article:

Columbia University student’s accused rapist speaks out

The Columbia University student who carried around a mattress as a symbol of her on campus rape told her assailant “I love you” weeks after the alleged attack, the accused student claimed Tuesday.

Paul Nungesser, who was accused by the futon-toting activist Emma Sulkowicz of raping her on Aug. 27, 2012, gave the Daily Beast some intimate exchanges he had with his fellow student, including that affectionate love note and other efforts by Sulkowicz to keep in touch after the sexual encounter.

“I feel like we need to have some real time where we can talk about life and thingz because we still haven’t really had a paul-emma chill sesh since summmmerrrr,” Sulkowicz wrote in a Facebook message to Nungesser on Aug. 29, 2012.

They exchanged a few more messages in the first two months of their sophomore year. Nungesser wished her a happy birthday, and Sulkowicz responded, “I love you Paul. Where are you?!?!?!?!”

Overall, the pair’s communication was “very amiable,” Nungesser told the Daily Beast. “Nothing was changed or different or weird or anything in her behavior." Sulkowicz confirmed the accuracy of the messages.

Sulkowicz has said that the pair had hooked up before the alleged assault, which started consensually, but turned violent, she said. Nungesser claims the entire incident was consensual. As evidence, he offered a Facebook message where he invited Sulkowicz to a party two days after the alleged rape, and she accepted.

Sulkowicz remembers those days differently, saying she did not initially report the rape out of embarrassment. When she did, later that year, Columbia found Nungesser “not responsible” for the incident.

She filed a police report against him in May 2014, putting Nungesser’s name in the public record, but she did not pursue a criminal case.

Instead, she created “Carry that Weight,” a bit of performance art activism in which she lugged a dorm mattress around to protest Nungesser’s presence on campus.

The project launched Sulkowicz, 22, to national fame, and even got her invited to the State of the Union address this year as a guest of Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand (D-N.Y.).

She has also been honored by the National Association for Women and has inspired college students across the country to carry mattresses in solidarity.

On Tuesday, she told the Daily News that she remained in contact with her rapist because she was confused.

“I reached out to Paul after he raped me,” she said. “I wanted to talk with him. I wanted to continue our friendship and ‘talk things out.’ This is hard for anyone who hasn't been raped by a close friend and lover to understand, but many people do not call the police after they have been raped.”

"Every rape has unique facts and circumstances. Subsequent conversations that take place post-alleged incident do not necessarily preclude that a prior nonconsensual act took place,” said Sonia Ossorio, president of the National Organization for Women-NYC.

Summary:
output: Paul Nungesser, the Columbia University student accused of raping Emma Sulkowicz, who carried a mattress around campus as a symbol of her alleged rape, has spoken out, claiming that Sulkowicz told him "I love you" weeks after the alleged attack. Nungesser has given the Daily Beast some intimate exchanges he had with Sulkowicz, including that affectionate love note and other efforts by Sulkowicz to keep in touch after the sexual encounter. Sulkowicz has said that the pair had hooked up before the alleged assault, which started consensually, but turned violent, she said. Nungesser claims the entire incident was consensual. As evidence, he offered a Facebook message where he invited Sulkowicz to a party two days after the alleged rape, and she accepted. Sulkowicz remembers those days differently, saying she did not initially report the rape out of embarrassment. When she did, later that year, Columbia found Nungesser “not responsible” for the incident.

The U.S. Supreme Court signaled Wednesday it may be open to new limits on the government's ability to track someone's movements by accessing data on that person's cellphone.  A case before the high court could result in a landmark decision in the ongoing debate over civil liberties protections in an era of rapid technological change.  At issue is whether law enforcement will be able to access cellphone data that can reveal a person's whereabouts without having to first obtain a court-issued search warrant.  The case stems from the conviction of Timothy Carpenter for a series of robberies back in 2010 and 2011. Prosecutors were able to obtain cellphone records that indicated his location over a period of months, information that proved crucial to his conviction. On Wednesday, lawyers for the American Civil Liberties Union argued that law enforcement should be required to obtain a court-ordered search warrant before obtaining such information.  They also argued that allowing law enforcement to access the cellphone data without a warrant would violate the prohibition on unreasonable search and seizures contained in the Fourth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution.  "It is impossible to go about our daily lives without leaving a trail of digital breadcrumbs that reveal where we have been over time, what we have done, who we spent time with," said ACLU attorney Nathan Freed Wessler, who spoke to reporters outside the Supreme Court following oral arguments. "It is time for the court, we think, to update Fourth Amendment doctrine to provide reasonable protections today."  Some of the justices also raised concerns about privacy in the digital age.  "Most Americans, I think, still want to avoid Big Brother," Justice Sonia Sotomayor, who often sides with the liberal wing of the court, said.  Chief Justice John Roberts, who often sides with conservatives on the court, said the central question was whether the cellphone information should be accessible to the government "without a warrant." Question: Who's case caused the debate? Options:  A. not enough information  B. Wessler  C. Freed  D. Carpenter  === The correct answer is
A:

To successfully apply to Yale University, follow this organized approach:

1. **Academic Excellence**: 
   - Enroll in the most challenging courses available, such as AP, IB, or dual enrollment programs, to demonstrate your ability to handle a rigorous academic load.

2. **Standardized Test Preparation**:

4. **Letters of Recommendation**:
   - Secure strong recommendations from teachers or mentors who can speak to your academic abilities and personal qualities. Aim for three letters, ensuring they are well-written and specific.

5. **Leadership and Extracurricular Involvement**:
   - Highlight leadership roles in clubs or community projects. Showcase how these experiences have prepared you for Yale's values of leadership and contribution to campus diversity.

6. **Interview Preparation**:
   - If an interview is required, prepare by practicing for tough questions and reflecting on how your experiences align with Yale's mission.

7. **Financial Considerations**:
   - Apply for need-based financial aid through Yale to reduce costs. Check the specific requirements and deadlines for this process.

8. **Application Timeline**:
   - Start early by researching Yale's requirements and deadlines. Ensure all materials, including the Common Application, are submitted on time.

9. **Seek Advice**:
   - Consult with counselors, teachers, or alumni for insights and tips on effectively presenting yourself to Yale's admissions committee.

By systematically addressing each area—academics, tests, essays, recommendations, leadership, interviews, finances, timeline, and seeking advice—you can enhance your application and increase your chances of admission to Yale.

input: Suggest a movie title for the following movie plot: It is sometime in the near future, in a fictional high-tech adult amusement park called Delos. The entertainment in all three areas consists primarily of interaction by the guests with androids programmed to act in character (the Old West, medieval Europe, and pre-Christian Rome, respectively). The androids are indistinguishable from human beings, apart from minor flaws in their hands, and guests are encouraged to indulge in any fantasy, including killing the androids. The androids are programmed to respond positively to guest requests, specifically including requests for sex. Delos's guests pay $1,000 a day for the experience.Peter Martin (Benjamin) a first-timer and his friend John Blane (Brolin), who has visited previously, come to the WesternWorld zone, where one of the main attractions is the Gunslinger (Yul Brynner), a robot programmed to start duels. Thanks to its programming, humans can always outdraw the Gunslinger and kill it. The guns issued to the guests also have temperature sensors that prevent them from firing at each other or anything else living but allow them to 'kill' the room-temperature androids.Gradually, the technicians running Delos begin to notice problems with the androids. In what may be the first mention of the concept of a computer virus in a film, the technical staff describe inexplicable problems and breakdowns spreading "like a disease" between the machines, first in one area of the park and then on to the others. First, the robots in MedievalWorld begin suffering an inexplicable number of systemic failures. Then, a robot rattlesnake strikes Blane. Against her programming, a female servant android refuses a guest's request for sex. The failures increase until the robotic Black Knight kills a guest in a sword-fight in MedievalWorld. The resort's supervisors, in increasing desperation, attempt to regain control by shutting down power to the entire park. Unfortunately, this results in trapping them...
output:

The movie title gives off an ominous yet intriguing vibe. Chronicles alludes to a saga or a series, leaving the door open to potential sequels or spin-offs in different zones or time periods, showcasing more of the fascinating world of Delos. It also suggests that the film will delve into the intricacies of the amusement park, branching out to explore the issues faced by the park staff, the technical glitches, and the park visitors' experiences.

"Android Rebellion" hooks the audience as it hints at the climax and central conflict of the story. It implies that the androids begin to malfunction and rebel against their programming and against the guests, raising questions about artificial intelligence ethics and the consequences of indulging in limitless fantasies.

By marrying these two key elements, "Chronicles of Delos: The Android Rebellion" creates a sense of mystery, wonder, and excitement, promising an unforgettable journey in an extraordinary world where fantasy transcends into reality, and the boundaries between life and technology are pushed to the limits. Furthermore, it provokes the audience's curiosity to witness how this once-ideal amusement park will deal with the unforeseen challenges and consequences of advanced technology gone awry.

system_prompt: Explain how you used the definition to come up with the answer.
input:
Given the task definition and input, reply with output. Given a document, generate a short title of the document. The title should convey the main idea/event/topic about which the document is being written. Note that URLs in the text have been replaced with [Link].

Days after  Chicago police Officer Dina Markham  was found dead in  her  bathtub  a break-in took place at  her  Northwest Side home while  her  family attended  her  wake  police records obtained by the Chicago Tribune show.
The disclosure of the still-unsolved âcriminal trespassâ to the residence June 2 adds to the mystery surrounding  Markham âs death as well as that of  her  husband  also a veteran Chicago police officer  whose gunshot death in the coupleâs bedroom 20 months earlier was ruled a suicide.
The FBI and county authorities were still investigating the shooting of Sgt.  Donald Markham  in the coupleâs bed when  his  widowâs body was discovered in the bathtub at the residence over the Memorial Day weekend.
The Cook County medical examinerâs office ruled Dina Markham  47  died May 28 of an accidental drowning after consuming a dangerous mix of alcohol and the powerful anti-anxiety drug alprazolam  commonly sold under the brand name Xanax.
Police had been called to the home in the Norwood Park neighborhood about 6 p.m. that evening after two of  Markham âs friends said they discovered her unresponsive in the water-filled bathtub.
According to records made public by the medical examiner   Markham  had texted a friend âHelp. Please ... no kiddingâ a little after 4 a.m. that day.
Five days after  Markham âs death  a police officer discovered a sliding door open at the back of the house in the 5900 block of North Newark Avenue while conducting a âpremise checkâ about 10:30 p.m. June 2  according to the records released through the Freedom of Information Act.
Two neighbors told police they didnât notice any activity at the house while the family attended Dina Markhamâs wake  according to the records.
In May  shortly before Dina Markham's death  at least two officers involved in the probe were interviewed at the state's attorney's offices about their roles in the investigation into Donald Markhamâs death  the Tribune has reported.
Records show that  Dina Markham told police her husband  51   had locked her out of  their  home the night of  his  death in September 2015 after the couple had been out drinking and argued after leaving a bar about 1 a.m.
In the 911 recordings released by the medical examinerâs office  a distraught Dina Markham told an emergency dispatcher that her husband was unresponsive and bleeding from his head. She pleaded that an ambulance come to the home.
Crime lab tests also showed Donald Markham had gunshot residue on his hand  indicating he'd either fired a gun or was close to a weapon being discharged at the time of his death  according to police records. The records do not indicate whether Dina Markham's hands were ever tested.
Jim Bastian   an attorney and close friend of Dina Markham's family   previously told the Tribune that Markham had "heard rumors" of an investigation but had not been contacted for an interview by any law enforcement agency before her death.
One of two friends who discovered her body told police that Dina Markham had called her twice at 3:59 a.m.  but  the friend  didn't answer the phone because  she  was sleeping  the reports show. Six minutes after the calls  Markham sent  the same friend  the text asking for help.
output: Mystery Surrounding the Death of Chicago Police Officer Dina Markham and Her Husband

Here is a news article: Fifty years ago, the Voting Rights Movement marched through Selma and over the Edmund Pettus Bridge. The marches across the bridge led to the passage of the 1965 Voting Rights Act, and today the bridge is a symbol of nonviolent victory for change! 
  
 Unfortunately, the bridge is STILL named after a man who served as Grand Dragon of the Alabama Ku Klux Klan, was a Confederate General, and was later elected as a United States Senator. 
  
 The bridge was the site of “Bloody Sunday”. On March 7, 1965, hundreds of nonviolent protesters attempted to march from Selma to Montgomery for their right to vote. But as they crossed the Edmund Pettus Bridge, they were met by Alabama state troopers and deputized civilians who were armed with billy clubs, tear gas, and cattle prods and attacked the marchers and drove them back to Brown Chapel Church. 
  
 How could a landmark that holds so much significance for the civil rights movement be named after a man who not only supported slavery, but held one of the highest positions within the Ku Klux Klan? 
  
 It's time for the state of Alabama, the city of Selma, and the National Park Service to remove a KKK leader's name from the historic bridge. 
  
 Selma and the Voting Rights Movement altered the course of history forever, and Selma has done too much for this country to remain unchanged. Selma is currently 80% African American, with a black mayor and majority African American local city officials. The name Edmund Pettus is far from what the city of Selma should honor. Let’s change the image of the bridge from hatred and rename it to memorialize hope and progress. 
  
 Please sign our petition calling on Selma and Alabama leaders and the National Park Service to rename the Edmund Pettus Bridge. ||||| A petition calling on political leaders to rename Selma's iconic Edmund Pettus Bridge has garnered more than 149,500 signatures, just shy of its organizers' goal of 150,000 names. 
  
 The bridge is one of the great physical icons of the U.S. civil rights movement, serving as a monument to the struggle for equality under law that came to a crescendo during the historic march on Selma in 1965. 
  
 Its place in the lore of American history holds firm 50 years after Bloody Sunday took place on the span, shocking people around the globe who watched the events unfold on live TV. 
  
 But many people are unaware that the bridge -- which was the centerpiece of a performance by Common and John Legend tied to the film "Selma" at this year's Oscars and will be visited by multiple U.S. presidents for a ceremony Saturday -- is also the center of a major controversy. 
  
 Edmund Pettus is known as the namesake of a bridge renowned throughout the world as a symbol of equality and racial justice. But it is named for an Alabama senator, confederate general and judge who also held a less honorable title: Grand Dragon of the state's Ku Klux Klan chapter. 
  
 That fact is behind the online petition, which calls on the U.S National Park Services, Alabama Gov. Robert Bentley and Selma Mayor George Patrick Evans to take the necessary steps "to remove a KKK leader's name from the historic bridge." 
  
 The petition, posted on Change.org by the activist group Students UNITE less than two weeks ago, states that "the marches across the bridge led to the passage of the 1965 Voting Rights Act, and today the bridge is a symbol of nonviolent victory for change! Unfortunately, the bridge is STILL named after a man who served as Grand Dragon of the Alabama Ku Klux Klan, was a Confederate General, and was later elected as a United States Senator." |||||
A summary of this is?
output: The Edmund Pettus Bridge in Selma, Alabama, which played a significant role in the civil rights movement, is named after a man who was a Grand Dragon of the Alabama Ku Klux Klan, a Confederate General, and a United States Senator. The bridge was the site of the infamous "Bloody Sunday" incident in 1965, where nonviolent protesters were attacked by state troopers and deputized civilians. A petition has been created to rename the bridge to honor hope and progress instead of hatred. The petition has gained over 149,500 signatures, just shy of its goal of 150,000. The controversy surrounding the bridge's name has brought attention to the fact that many people are unaware of its namesake's history. The bridge is a symbol of equality and racial justice, but its name does not reflect those values.

That's pretty shocking because he's such a negative figure, yet the bridge is honoring him.

The article then describes the "Bloody Sunday" event on March 7, 1965, where marchers were attacked by state troopers and others with weapons, leading to a significant moment in the civil rights movement. So, the bridge is a place of both historical significance and controversy because of Pettus's background.

The petition mentioned is aiming to rename the bridge, arguing that honoring someone with Pettus's history is inappropriate given Selma's majority African American population and its role in the civil rights movement. The petition has over 149,500 signatures, close to their goal of 150,000. The bridge is also a major site visited by many, including presidents, for events commemorating the Voting Rights Act.

I'm thinking the key points are the historical importance of the bridge, the problematic name origin, the recent push for renaming, and the public response through the petition. **Summary of the News Article:**

The Edmund Pettus Bridge in Selma, Alabama, is a pivotal symbol of the U.S. civil rights movement, notably featured in the 1965 Voting Rights Act. However, it is controversially named after Edmund Pettus, a former Ku Klux Klan leader, Confederate general, and U.S. Senator, whose legacy is marked by racism and oppression.

The bridge gained international attention during "Bloody Sunday," a violent encounter where nonviolent protesters were attacked while marching from Selma to Montgomery. This event galvanized support for the Voting Rights Act.

Currently, a petition campaign seeks to rename the bridge, arguing that honoring Pettus, given his extremist past, is inconsistent with Selma's progress and its predominantly African American population. The petition, with over 149,500 signatures, calls for the bridge's renaming, emphasizing the need to align its legacy with the values of equality and justice it represents.

This debate highlights the tension between historical significance and the ethical implications of naming, prompting a reconsideration of the bridge's moniker in the context of its role in civil rights history.

**Movie Plot: "Shadows of the City"**

**Title:** Shadows of the City  
**Genre:** Action/Crime/Thriller  
**Logline:** A reluctant partnership between a former detective and a notorious crime lord, orchestrated by the police, unravels a web of corruption and betrayal in a gritty urban setting.

**Setting:** A sprawling, corrupt city where underground crime thrives. The story unfolds in a mix of neon-lit streets, shadowy alleys, and the imposing halls of power.

**Characters:**
- **Jack:** A brooding former detective with a mysterious past, haunted by his actions and seeking redemption.
- **Demarkov:** A cunning crime lord with a reputation for ruthlessness, whose past intersects with Jack's in unexpected ways.
- **Detective Maria:** The police officer who initiates the confrontation, harboring her own secrets and motivations.
- **Agent Carter:** A mole within Demarkov's organization, providing crucial intelligence to the police.

**Plot Structure:**

1. **The Approach:** Jack is pulled from his quiet life when Detective Maria visits him, revealing that Demarkov is involved in a series of high-profile crimes. She proposes a partnership, leveraging Jack's expertise against Demarkov's influence.

2. **The Reluctant Partnership:** Jack reluctantly agrees, driven by a desire to uncover the truth about his past. The two begin their tense journey, meeting in public places where their shared goal of taking down a greater threat becomes clear.

3. **The Confrontation:** The confrontation is arranged in a public setting, designed to draw attention. The meeting turns chaotic, with both Jack and Demarkov revealing their true colors, testing each other's limits.

4. **The Twist:** During the confrontation, Maria reveals that the real threat is a powerful syndicate manipulating both Jack and Demarkov. The confrontation was a distraction, and the true enemy is someone else.

5. **The Climax:** Jack and Demarkov, now aware of the larger threat, must team up against a new adversary, uncovering past connections that put them in danger. Their collaboration leads to a climactic showdown, where secrets are revealed, and old wounds are healed.

6. **The Resolution:** The duo emerges victorious, but not without cost. Jack faces his past, while Demarkov finds redemption, leaving the city with a chance for change. The movie ends on a note of hope, though Jack remains a loner, forever haunted by his choices.

**Themes:** The film explores themes of trust, redemption, and the moral ambiguity of heroism, highlighting that even the greatest villains have stories worth understanding.

**Conclusion:** "Shadows of the City" is a tale of reluctant alliances and the complexities of morality, set against a backdrop of urban decay and intrigue, offering a gripping narrative of redemption and sacrifice.

output:
To solve the given equation, 0 = -561*a + 560*a for the variable 'a', follow these steps:

Step 1: Combine like terms on one side of the equation.
Since both terms on the right-hand side of the equation contain 'a', you can combine them by adding the coefficients of each term together. 

0 = -561*a + 560*a

Step 2: Add the coefficients of the terms containing 'a'.
The equation now becomes:

0 = (-561 + 560)*a

Computing the value of the sum (-561 + 560):

-561 + 560 = -1

So the equation now is:

0 = -1*a

Step 3: Solve for 'a'.
To find the value of 'a', divide both sides of the equation by the coefficient of 'a' which is -1.

0 / -1 = (-1*a) / -1

0 = a

The solution to the equation 0 = -561*a + 560*a is a = 0.

He obtained a queen's scholarship at the Royal Academy of Music, studied under William Sterndale Bennett and developed into an accomplished pianist, visiting Germany to study in 1857 and playing Mendelssohn's Piano Concerto No. 2 in D minor at a Gewandhaus concert at Leipzig in 1860. His teachers at the Conservatoire in Leipzig included the great pianist Ignaz Moscheles, who had been a pupil of Beethoven. Back in Britain, Barnett enjoyed a successful career as a pianist for some years but concentrated increasingly on composition and teaching. He became noticed as a composer with his symphony in A minor (1864), and followed this with a number of compositions for orchestra, strings and piano. His cantata The Ancient Mariner premiered at Birmingham in 1867, and another, Paradise and the Peri, in 1870, both successfully. In 1873 his most important work, the oratorio The Raising of Lazarus, was written, and in 1876 produced at Hereford. During this period, Barnett also composed several other minor cantatas and piano pieces, and he took an active part as a professor at the Guildhall School of Music and one of the founder-professors of the Royal College of Music, where his students included Marmaduke Barton.

system_prompt: You are an AI assistant. You will be given a task. You must generate a detailed and long answer.
input:
Read this and answer the question. If the question is unanswerable, say "unanswerable".

Besides emptiness, Mahayana schools often place emphasis on the notions of perfected spiritual insight (prajñāpāramitā) and Buddha-nature (tathāgatagarbha). There are conflicting interpretations of the tathāgatagarbha in Mahāyāna thought. The idea may be traced to Abhidharma, and ultimately to statements of the Buddha in the Nikāyas. In Tibetan Buddhism, according to the Sakya school, tathāgatagarbha is the inseparability of the clarity and emptiness of one's mind. In Nyingma, tathāgatagarbha also generally refers to inseparability of the clarity and emptiness of one's mind. According to the Gelug school, it is the potential for sentient beings to awaken since they are empty (i.e. dependently originated). According to the Jonang school, it refers to the innate qualities of the mind that expresses themselves as omniscience etc. when adventitious obscurations are removed. The "Tathāgatagarbha Sutras" are a collection of Mahayana sutras that present a unique model of Buddha-nature. Even though this collection was generally ignored in India, East Asian Buddhism provides some significance to these texts.

According to what school does it refer to the innate qualities of the mind that express themselves as omniscience?
output: According to the Jonang school, tathāgatagarbha refers to the innate qualities of the mind that express themselves as omniscience, etc., when adventitious obscurations are removed.

When it comes to painting furniture, there are a few key steps that you need to follow in order to achieve a professional-looking finish. One of the most important steps is preparing the surface of the furniture before you begin painting. This involves cleaning the surface, sanding it down if necessary, and applying a primer if you're working with a particularly slick or shiny surface.

Once you've prepared the surface, it's time to start painting. Depending on the type of paint you're using, you may need to thin it out with a little bit of water or another solvent before you begin. This will help the paint go on more smoothly and evenly, and will also help it dry faster.

When you're ready to start painting, it's important to apply the paint in thin, even coats. This will help prevent drips and runs, and will also help the paint dry more quickly. If you're working with a particularly large or complex piece of furniture, you may need to apply multiple coats of paint in order to achieve the desired level of coverage.

Between coats, it's important to let the paint dry completely. This will usually take several hours, depending on the type of paint you're using and the temperature and humidity of your workspace. If you try to apply a second coat of paint before the first coat is completely dry, you may end up with a streaky or uneven finish.

Once you've applied all of the necessary coats of paint, it's time to wipe down the surface of the furniture. This will help remove any dust or debris that may have accumulated during the painting process, and will also help smooth out any rough spots or imperfections in the finish.

Overall, painting furniture can be a fun and rewarding DIY project, but it's important to take your time and follow the proper steps in order to achieve the best possible results. By preparing the surface, applying the paint in thin, even coats, letting it dry between coats, and wiping it off at the end, you can create a beautiful and long-lasting finish that will look great for years to come.
